message.content: We refer to the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons for help. The patient has Erb’s palsy, a condition commonly caused by a traumatic birth injury. Treatment includes pinning the affected arm’s sleeve to the shirt and gentle physical therapy exercises. Splinting may worsen the condition and an MRI is not necessary for diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The given scenario suggests a clavicle fracture, which is a common birth injury. The most appropriate next step in management for a clavicle fracture is pinning the affected arm to the shirt to prevent movement and promote proper healing. Physical therapy and splinting may be required later in the management, but pinning the sleeve to the shirt is the first and most important step. MRI is not required for the diagnosis of a clavicle fracture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a depressed left clavicle fracture, which is a common birth injury. Pinning the sleeve to the shirt can prevent accidental movement of the arm and allow healing of the fracture. Physical therapy and splinting may not be necessary, as the fracture usually heals spontaneously. MRI is not necessary for the diagnosis or management of the fracture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a clavicle fracture, and pinning the sleeve to the shirt is usually sufficient for management. Physical therapy may be indicated later if necessary, but not as the initial step. Splinting is not usually recommended for clavicle fractures. MRI is not necessary for diagnosis and management of clavicle fractures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a clavicular fracture. Pinning the sleeve to the shirt will provide support and immobilization of the affected arm, which is the appropriate first step in management. Physical therapy and splinting may be indicated later in the course of management. MRI is not necessary for diagnosis and management of a clavicular fracture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is consistent with a clavicle fracture. Pinning the sleeve to the shirt will immobilize the arm and allow proper healing. Physical therapy and splinting may not be necessary for this type of fracture, and an MRI is not typically necessary for diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest a clavicle fracture. Pinning the sleeve to the shirt is a common treatment to stabilize the arm while the fracture heals. Physical therapy may be helpful later on in the healing process, but it is not the most appropriate next step. Splinting may not be effective in this case as it may not hold the bone fragments together. MRI is not needed for diagnosis and management of clavicle fracture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a diagnosis of a clavicular fracture. Pin sleeve to shirt is the most appropriate next step in management as it will help support the clavicle and minimize movement until the fracture heals. Physical therapy may be needed later on, but not as the first step. Splinting of the arm and MRI of the clavicle are not necessary for the management of a clavicular fracture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests a clavicular fracture. Pinning the sleeve to the shirt will help relieve the tension from the fractured clavicle and promote healing. Physical therapy and splinting may be considered later on in the healing process. MRI is not necessary for diagnosis and management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description suggests a case of neonatal clavicular fracture. Pinning the sleeve to the shirt reduces movement of the affected arm and facilitates healing. Physical therapy is not recommended at this stage, and splinting or MRI is not necessary.
